item.title: Report E-2024070389
item.description:
Report E-2024070389

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-11
  • City: YPSILANTI
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 11, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN3109 had a faulty lid and released approximately three (3) ounces of product to the cap of the tote. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE unscrewed the lid, and replaced it with a brand new vented lid. The damaged lid was placed into one (1) 5-gallon container which was left onsite.

item.title: Report E-2024070417
item.description:
Report E-2024070417

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-26
  • City: GARDEN CITY
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO- XDE contacted ERTS regarding a leaking 250-gallon metal tote containing hazardous product, Zinc Octoate 8%. A Contractor discovered that the lid to the tote was loose and likely the cause of the release. It was estimated that 5-gallons of product spilled from the lid impacting the metal tote itself, the wooden trailer floor, and the steel grate on trailer floor. The total impact are was estimated to be 6’x6’. The Contractor was able to tighten the lid and perform a slosh test confirming that adjustments made to the lid were successful and the tote is in proper working order to ship on to the Consignee. One 55-gallon DM was generated for waste disposal containing impacted cardboard, PPE, and absorbent pads/rags. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident
